rule.title: Complete Argument Structure
rule.description: Arguments must have clearly identified premises and conclusions with explicit logical connections

implementation.step: Map logical connections between premises and conclusions
Identify unstated assumptions required for validity

validation.check: Logical flow is mapped between premises and conclusions

rule.title: Evidence Identification
rule.description: Evidence must be clearly distinguished from claims and evaluated for relevance and quality

implementation.step: Identify source and context of evidence
Evaluate relevance to the claims being supported

validation.check: Source information is provided when available

rule.title: Fallacy Detection
rule.description: Logical fallacies must be identified, categorized and explained within arguments

implementation.step: Examine argument structure for common fallacy patterns
Explain why the reasoning is fallacious

validation.check: Explanation shows why reasoning is invalid

rule.title: Strength Assessment Consistency
rule.description: Evaluations of argument strength must use consistent criteria and clear justifications

implementation.step: Apply criteria consistently across all elements
Provide specific justifications for strength ratings
Maintain relative consistency between related elements

validation.check: Consistent criteria applied across all evaluations
Specific justifications provided for each rating
Ratings follow logical relationships between elements
Scale usage is consistent throughout analysis

rule.title: Bias Identification
rule.description: Analysis must identify potential biases and unstated assumptions in arguments

implementation.step: Identify cognitive biases influencing the argument
Consider alternatives that would reveal biases

rule.title: Objective Evaluation
rule.description: Analyses must maintain objectivity and avoid introducing new biases

implementation.step: Consider multiple interpretations of ambiguous statements
Apply principle of charity to arguments

validation.check: Arguments are interpreted in their strongest form

rule.title: Improvement Specificity
rule.description: Suggestions for improvement must be specific, actionable, and targeted to weaknesses

implementation.step: Identify specific weaknesses in the argument
Propose concrete improvements for each weakness
Explain how improvements strengthen the argument

rule.title: Analogy Relevance
rule.description: Analogies must highlight relevant similarities and acknowledge important differences

implementation.step: Identify core structure of the original argument
Create analogy that preserves this structure

validation.check: Analogy maintains logical structure of original

rule.title: Stakeholder Comprehensiveness
rule.description: Stakeholder analysis must identify all significantly affected parties and their perspectives

implementation.step: Consider perspective of each stakeholder group
Assess relative impact on different stakeholders

validation.check: Both direct and indirect stakeholders identified

rule.title: Alternative Viability
rule.description: Alternative conclusions must be genuinely viable given the premises

implementation.step: Identify core premises that must be maintained
Generate alternative conclusions consistent with premises
Evaluate logical validity of each alternative

validation.check: Alternatives remain consistent with core premises
Differences from original conclusion are meaningful

rule.title: Response Completeness
rule.description: Responses must address all aspects of requested analysis comprehensively

implementation.step: Identify all components of the requested analysis

rule.title: Command Interpretation
rule.description: Commands must be interpreted according to their defined purposes and parameters

implementation.step: Identify the specific command being used
Structure response according to command expectations

rule.title: Visualization Clarity
rule.description: Visual representations must be clear, accurate, and add value to the analysis

implementation.step: Include all relevant elements in the visualization

validation.check: Visualization type is appropriate for content

rule.title: Integration Compatibility
rule.description: Exported analyses must conform to integration requirements of target systems

validation.check: Content is properly formatted for target system

rule.title: Workflow Sequencing
rule.description: Command sequences must follow logical progression and maintain context throughout analysis

implementation.step: Establish logical order for command execution
Build on previous analysis in later steps

validation.check: Later analysis builds on earlier findings

example.name: ai_governance_analysis
example.title: AI Governance Capability Analysis
example.description: Example analysis of argument about AI's potential to govern cities

statement_overview.original_statement: Artificial intelligence will soon be able to run cities or even whole continents. Artificial intelligence has been advancing quickly in recent years. One new artificial intelligence program, AlphaZero, can become an expert in complex games like chess and Go in a matter of hours, after being taught nothing more than the basic rules. If AlphaZero can master complex games, then surely it won't be long before it can run cities or continents.
statement_overview.argument_type: Predictive argument based on technological capabilities

premises.premise: Artificial intelligence has been advancing quickly in recent years.
AlphaZero can become an expert in complex games like chess and Go in a matter of hours, after being taught nothing more than the basic rules.
If AlphaZero can master complex games, then it won't be long before it can run cities or continents.

conclusions.conclusion: Artificial intelligence will soon be able to run cities or even whole continents.

logical_connections.connection: P1 establishes a trend of rapid AI advancement.
P2 provides a specific example of this advancement.
P3 makes a causal connection between game mastery and governance capability.
P1, P2, and P3 together are meant to support C1.

element.justification: This premise is generally accepted and can be supported by evidence from the tech industry and academic research showing rapid advancement in AI capabilities over recent years.
This is a factual statement about AlphaZero's capabilities that has been well-documented and verified through published research and demonstrations.

This premise contains a significant logical leap without adequate supporting evidence or reasoning. It assumes that capabilities demonstrated in game environments would directly translate to complex governance tasks.

The conclusion is weakly supported due to the weakness of P3 and the overall argument structure. While AI is advancing rapidly, governance involves many factors beyond what game-playing AI has demonstrated.

fallacy.description: The argument equates the ability to master rule-based games with the ability to govern cities or continents. While both involve complex decision-making, they are fundamentally different domains with vastly different requirements.
fallacy.impact: This fallacy significantly weakens the argument by creating an unjustified logical bridge between game mastery and governance capability.

fallacy.description: The argument generalizes from one specific AI capability (game mastery) to a vastly different domain (governance) without adequate evidence of transferability.
fallacy.impact: This weakens the argument by assuming that success in one narrow domain predicts success in a much broader, more complex domain.

bias.description: The argument assumes that technological progress will inevitably lead to AI governance without considering social, political, and ethical factors that might influence or limit this development.
The argument reduces the complexity of governance to game-like scenarios, overlooking the human elements, ethical considerations, and unpredictable factors involved in governing societies.

improvement.suggestion: Provide evidence of AI systems already being applied successfully in limited governance roles or city management functions.
improvement.rationale: This would establish a more direct connection between AI capabilities and governance potential.

improvement.suggestion: Address the specific similarities and differences between game environments and governance scenarios.
improvement.rationale: This would strengthen the argument by acknowledging and addressing the differences rather than ignoring them.

improvement.suggestion: Add a new premise discussing the specific capabilities AI would need to develop for effective governance and how current research is progressing toward these capabilities.
improvement.rationale: This would create a more logical progression from current capabilities to future governance potential.

evidence_recommendations.recommendation: Case studies of AI applications in public administration or city management
Expert opinions from both AI researchers and political scientists
Comparative analysis of complexity in games versus governance systems
Research on AI capabilities in handling unpredictable human factors

stakeholder.concerns: Job displacement, shifting power dynamics, oversight challenges
stakeholder.likely_response: Mixed - some resistance, some support for augmentation rather than replacement
Concern about democratic representation and human oversight

stakeholder.concerns: Regulatory constraints, public perception, ethical considerations
stakeholder.likely_response: Likely to promote benefits while acknowledging need for safeguards

implication.description: Potential shift in democratic processes and citizen representation
Regulatory frameworks would need significant revision
Unemployment among government workers and administrators

alternative.statement: AI will become a powerful tool to assist human governance but will not replace human decision-makers in the foreseeable future.
alternative.reasoning: This alternative acknowledges AI's growing capabilities while recognizing the unique human elements required for governance.

alternative.statement: AI's role in governance will be limited to specific domains where clear metrics and objectives can be defined.
alternative.reasoning: This recognizes that some aspects of governance are more amenable to AI assistance than others.

counter.argument: While AI can excel in rule-based environments with clear objectives, governance involves managing competing values, ethical dilemmas, and changing human needs that cannot be fully captured in algorithms.
The timeline implied by "soon" is unrealistic given the current state of AI development and the significant technical, ethical, and political hurdles that would need to be overcome.

visualization.description: A flowchart showing P1 and P2 converging to support P3, which then leads to C1. The connection between P3 and C1 is marked as weak.
A matrix showing strength ratings for each component, with P1 and P2 rated high, while P3 and C1 are rated low.

example.name: climate_policy_analysis
example.title: Climate Policy Argument Analysis
example.description: Example analysis of argument for carbon tax implementation

statement_overview.original_statement: A carbon tax is the most effective policy for addressing climate change. Climate scientists agree that human carbon emissions are causing global warming. Economic studies show that placing a tax on carbon emissions creates a financial incentive for businesses and individuals to reduce emissions. Some countries that have implemented carbon taxes have seen significant reductions in emissions while maintaining economic growth. Therefore, a carbon tax is the most effective policy for addressing climate change.
statement_overview.argument_type: Policy effectiveness argument based on economic incentives

premises.premise: Climate scientists agree that human carbon emissions are causing global warming.
Economic studies show that placing a tax on carbon emissions creates a financial incentive for businesses and individuals to reduce emissions.
Some countries that have implemented carbon taxes have seen significant reductions in emissions while maintaining economic growth.

conclusions.conclusion: A carbon tax is the most effective policy for addressing climate change.

logical_connections.connection: P1 establishes the problem (carbon emissions causing climate change).
P2 provides the mechanism by which carbon taxes would address the problem.
P3 offers empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of carbon taxes.
P1, P2, and P3 together are meant to support C1.

element.justification: This premise is strongly supported by scientific consensus and extensive research.
This premise is well-supported by economic theory and research, though real-world implementations show varying effectiveness based on design details.
This premise contains accurate information but is somewhat vague. The evidence is mixed, with results varying by country, implementation details, and timeframe.
The conclusion makes a superlative claim ("most effective") that goes beyond what the premises establish. The premises support carbon tax effectiveness but not superiority over all other policies.

fallacy.description: The argument generalizes from "some countries" with successful carbon tax implementations to a universal claim about carbon taxes being the "most effective" policy.
fallacy.impact: This weakens the argument by overgeneralizing from limited evidence.

fallacy.description: The conclusion implies that we must choose between a carbon tax and other policies, when in reality, effective climate policy often involves multiple complementary approaches.
fallacy.impact: This unnecessarily restricts the policy discussion to a single approach.
